title: five-things-east-lothian-weekend
story: The Courier has put together a list of five of the top things to do between this eveningand Sunday.Whether it is gala day celebrations or caber-tossing and tug-of-war, there is something for everyone.. Nungate GalaA SPECIAL tartan is to be unveiled this weekend to mark the Nungate Gala celebrations.Last year, a call was made for Nungate residents to come up with their own design for a Nungate Tartan.More than a dozen entries were submitted, with the design of local resident Kate Cowan coming out on top.The concept was then registered and produced by Strathmore Weavers.Gala celebrations get under way at noon tomorrowand run through to pm.The crowning of this yearrsquos Gala Queen, Olivia McCulloch, takes place at .pm followed by a procession through Haddington.Among the attractions at the gala are a bonnie baby and fancy dress competition, as well as plenty for youngsters including bouncy castles and other rides.There will also be a demonstration from WL Wrestling to mark the rd Nungate Gala.. North Berwick Highland GamesA HUGE crowd is expected at tomorrowsNorth Berwick International Highland Games.The Recreation Park gathering is the Gamesrsquo th anniversary.There is lots on offer from traditional heavy events to music, sport, childrenrsquos rides and trade stalls.Performances from  pipe bands from more than  countries give the day a truly international feel.Highland dancers of ious ages will be performing a number of traditional Scottish dances to crowds in the south west corner of the park.The heavy events include tossing the caber, throwing the hammer and tug of war.The main arena will play host to a -yard sprint for the first time, with ious handicap races planned.Around the park, there will be ious craft and trade stalls, childrenrsquos rides and a demonstration from the Lammermuir Stick Dressing Society.The Games begin at am at Recreation Park.. Fringe by the SeaWHETHER you like comedy, literature or live music, there is plenty on on offer in North Berwick.The curtain comes down on Fringe by the Sea on Sunday but there is still much to see before then.Tomorrow , Channel  journalist Cathy Newman is in the Simpson and Marwick Spiegeltent at am.We know of Emmeline Pankhurst, Vera Brittain, Marie Stopes and Beatrice Webb.But who remembers engineer and motorbike racer Beatrice Shilling, who fixed an often-fatal flaw in the Spitfire, allowing the RAFrsquos planes to soar to victory Cathy Newmans book Bloody Brilliant Women looks at some of the pioneering women in history.Then, at pm, in the same venue, there is a chance to hear from Ian Rankin.The much-celebrated Scottish author has seen his books starring John Rebus translated into  dferent languages and sold in their millions.Eddi Reader rounds off the night on Saturday from pm.Then, on Sunday, Lord David Steel is in conversation with Gordon Brown from noon in the Simpson and Marwick Spiegeltent.A Pet Shop Boys Tribute then performs at pm in the same venue.For more, go to www.fringebythesea. Ladies Scottish OpenTOP quality golfing is on display at The Renaissance Club tomorrowand Sunday.The Aberdeen Standard Investments Ladies Scottish Open is due to come to a close on Sunday.Thailands Ariya Jutanugarn won the competition  months ago at nearby Gullane Golf Club but can she repeat the feat at another county course Unfortunately, it looks like Catriona Matthews chances of winning are over.The North Berwick-based golfer is on + after completing her two rounds and is unlikely to make the cut.Entry to the event is free of charge.. FootballTHREE of the countys senior football teams are at home on Saturday.Haddington Athletic welcome Leith Athletic along the A to Millfield.The visitors sit second in the table with two wins and a draw from the opening three games.Meanwhile, Joe Hamills Hi Hi know they cannot afford many slip ups in a league where only one team is guaranteed promotion.They have picked up four points from their opening three games and will be hoping that home advantage is key.Alex Jack Cup action takes centre stage in Dunbar and Musselburgh.Dunbar United have enjoyed a promising start to their Premier Division season and will be looking to back that up against Dunipace.The Denny-based side are in the same league as Haddington Athletic and have six points from their opening three games.Finally, Musselburgh welcome Peebles Rovers - another Conference A team - to Olive Bank.The visitorsare yet to taste victory this season, with Musselburgh having picked up a - win over Sauchie Juniors last time out.All three games kick-off at .pm.

title: face-face-roy-hattersley-never-time-confused
story: And yet, the question in  is how misleading a picture is that view from his window  Does England even feel like England anymore ldquoAs a country  he asks in that familiar voice once so exaggerated and mocked by Spitting Image. ldquoThere has never been a time when wersquove been more confused. Therersquos never been a time when we have done what I believe we are doing now, which is imposing on ourselves a massive, self-inflicted wound. Leaving the European community, in my view, is deeply damaging to Britainrsquos future. Leaving it without an arrangement, without a treaty, is even worse. Itrsquos doubly damaging. Itrsquos almost inconceivable that we have got ourselves into this position.Welcome, in other words, to Brexitannia. Monday afternoon in the Peak District. On the TV, England are losing the First Test against Australia. The worry is thatrsquos not all the countryrsquos losing. Where stands England  Scotland later.Read More: Alison Rowat on Scottish LabourHattersley is  now. He retired from the House of Lords in , but his lelong interest in and passion for politicsremains intact. And he is as engaged in the principal issue of the day as the rest of us. Not that he is any clearer as to what is going to happen.ldquoItrsquos very dficult to predict what this Prime Minister will do because he has said so many dferent things. He talks about leaving at any cost. He talks about there being a one-in-a-million chance of a No Deal Brexit. I donrsquot think he knows. I donrsquot think anybody knows. I think wersquore flying blind and I think that is deeply dangerous for the country.And how does he feel about that  ldquoExasperation and anger and in a sense, fear. Not for me. Irsquom  and Irsquom comparatively prosperous. One of the things that irks me particularly about leaving the Community is that it wonrsquot be people like me who will suffer. It will be people at the bottom of the heap. It will be the disadvantaged and the dispossessed. It will be generations in -or--yearsrsquo time. We are mortgaging the future of the least well off, and thatrsquos alien to all I believe in.And where in all this does his own party stand  Whither Labour  Does he know  ldquoNo. One of my complaints is we have failed to adopt a serious position over the great issue of our time, perhaps the great issue of the century where Britainrsquos future lies. Our party doesnrsquot have a firm position in either direction.Note that ldquowe. Hattersley remains a Labour man through and through. He is probably best known for his time as the partyrsquos deputy leader through the s when Neil Kinnock was trying tothe party to power during the Thatcher years. He was always seen to be on the right of the party, although today he declares himself a ldquoradical socialist. And he was critical of the Blair government at the turn of the century. The question today is what he feels about the party now.Later this week he is in Scotland to tell us. He is appearing at the Edinburgh International Book Festival to talk about the future of the party he has served for so long. What hersquos actually going to say, though, hersquos slightly reluctant to tell me.ldquoThere are a number of things the Labour party has to do to recover and get itself back into the mainstream of politics, he argues. ldquoBut Irsquom not going to tell you what they are. Otherwise, no one will come.For a few minutes we circle around the subject. Is the leadership part of the problem, I ask  ldquoYes. And I shall deal with that.Can that be changed  ldquoYou are going into forbidden territory, he says, laughing.Well, would it be fair to say that Corbynism is a kind of mirror image of Blairism, both movements in their own way deeply inimical to what the Labour party should stand for ldquoNo. I had very many reservations about New Labour because I am a radical socialist and Irsquom not sure they were. I believe in equality and Irsquom not sure they did. Some people will blame Corbynism on New Labour and the Third Way, but I donrsquot believe they are responsible for it. I believe that Blairrsquos was a good government that made one terrible mistake with Iraq. But, my word,Tony was leading the Labour party now, I think it would look very dferent.The ultimate question that must be asked, I suggest, is what Labour stands for now. ldquoYou are asking the fundamental question Irsquom addressing on Thursday. What is the Labour party for  And Irsquom going to say we havenrsquot made it clear what wersquore for. We were always, since our foundation, reluctant to talk about the principles, the ideology. Wersquod just rather get on with it. And now is a time when we have to define what we are for, what we are about.Whatever his opinion of the current Labour leadershipHattersley thinks there is no shortage of talent on the Labour benches. ldquoThe parliamentary party is more full of talent than any time in my political experience. Night after night you put Newsnight or Channel  News on and some backbencher yoursquove never heard of ndash quite often a young woman ndash will speak with immense ability, grasp, confidence, understanding. The parliamentary Labour party is full of people of very high quality. They need to say what we stand for.When it comes to Scotland, he is, as you might expect, a Unionist. ldquoBut I understand part of the reason for Scottish nationalism. And part of the reason is not just the desire for independence. Itrsquos that the Scottish National Party filled the radical vacuum that was in part left by Blairism. The Labour party lost some of its radical edge and the SNP took over. So,we had a genuinely radical Labour party ndash not an extreme Labour party ndash I think Labour would do much better than it is doing in Scotland.That may be wishful thinking on his part. But then, as he says, he can recall a time when Scotland had no Tory MPs. Hattersleyrsquos political le covers most of the post-war period and the sht from welfare state consensus to the confused, atomised, political present. He was born in  and served as the MP for Birmingham Sparkbrook from  to .He also had, as politicians of his era did, a hinterland. Hattersley has also been a successful writer. In his last book, Catholics, published two years ago, he revealed that his mother Enid OrsquoHara, ran away with a priest, Frederick Hattersley, two weeks after he had officiated at her wedding to another man. Itrsquos a remarkable revelation. Did learning his fatherrsquos story change how he looked back on his own le, I wonder  He thinks not.ldquoI wish I had known about it because my father and I were very close. But he was a very self-effacing, retiring, shy sort of man and I would have liked to known about this heroic moment in his le when he did this, in my view, wonderful thing. And it makes me unhappy because I think he didnrsquot tell me because he thought I would be ashamed of him. In fact, I would have been very proud of him and I wish I had known about it.When he was  Hattersley read a book about equality and it changed his le. Politics suddenly seemed a worthy ambition. The frustration may be that, after serving in the Harold Wilson and Jim Callaghan governments in the late s and through the s, he spent the rest of his political career in opposition as Labour toiled during the s and early s.What he did achieve in that time was to see off Militant, one of the things, Hattersley says, he feels most proud of. ldquoFor two or three years, two or three of us, two of us really, John Smith and me, spent our time going around the country saying the Labour party is better than it sounds. Speaking out for the real Labour party in the country. And somebody needs to do that again. Because some of the old people, literally some of those expelled years ago, are now back with card-carrying Labour membership doing the damage they did before. So, we must go over all that ground again. And I hope some people will emerge who will do it.John Smithrsquos untimely death in  left us pondering one of the great what s of modern British politics. Whathe had lived to lead the Labour Party into the  general election  Hattersley is in no doubt.ldquoIf John had lived, we would have had a proper Labour government. He would have won the election. He probably wouldnrsquot have won it with as big a majority as Tony. Tony reached middle classes that John probably wouldnrsquot have reached. But he would have certainly won the election. And not only would Britain have changed, the world would have changed, too. We wouldnrsquot have had Iraq. The damage that was done to Britain and the world from John Smithrsquos death is incalculable.Roy Hattersley will discuss ldquoThe Labour Partyrsquos Future this Thursday at the Edinburgh International Book Festival, at .pm.

title: iain-macwhirter-john-mcdonnells-edinburgh-declaration-caught-scottish-political-world-completely-surprise
story: If anyone tells you that theyd expected this, theyre lying. McDonnells Edinburgh Declaration caught the Scottish political world completely by surprise. The SNP couldnt believe their ears. I initially thought his remarks, especially the reference to ldquothe English Parliament, were just a badly-briefed UK politician talking off the cuff. But no. It is now apparently UK Labour policy to accept the SNPrsquos call for ldquoindyref. Gobs were well and truly smacked.Most smacked of all were the Scottish Labour Partys. Their leader, Richard Leonard, was left speechless. The Shadow Chancellor had directly contradicted Labours  manesto promise to oppose a repeat referendum. Only in March, Leonard made clear in an interview with the Daily Record, that a future Labour government would, like Theresa May, refuse any request for a ldquoSection  Order to trigger a legally-binding referendum on independence. No s no buts.:Scottish Labour registers lowest level of income in nearly two decadesNot any more, it seems. The Branch Office, as the SNP like to call Scottish Labour, has been told to back the policy of their deadly enemy. Christmas has come early for Nicola Sturgeon, without the turkeys.Many Scottish Labour MSPs were incandescent, as was the former Labour shadow Scottish secretary Ian Murray MP, who called McDonnell ldquoludicrous and demanded that he ldquoapologise to Richard Leonard , and reaffirm Labours policy of opposition to a referendum . Off-the-record comments from Scottish Labour figures were unprintable. Unionist Labour MSPs put together a statement ldquodeploring" the change in policy. This backfired when it emerged they hadnt cleared it with Richard Leonards office.The Labour MP, Paul Sweeney, then added to the confusion by calling for a multi-option referendum including federalism, or devo max as it used to be called. This was once proposed by Alex Salmond in , and rejected by Labour and the Conservatives in favour of a binary Yes No question. Saying Labour were all over the place would be an insult to geography.So, what on earth is going on  Why was one of the key figures in the UK Labour party provoking a split on one of the most contentious issues in British politics  And right in the middle of the Brexit row. Labour is now ided every which way on the constitution: over Scottish independence and over leaving Europe. McDonnell has left the Scottish party an impossible task: trying to win Scottish votes without a policy on Scotland in a general election thats possibly weeks away.:Scottish Labour breaks silence over anti-semitism investigation by blasting "biased" BBCWhat seems to have happened is this. Labour, at a UK level, has started to think about forming much wider political alliances in future in order to defeat the rising tide of the right. This has been discussed by a number of Labour people, including the former BBC economics editor Paul Mason in his book Clear Bright Future.Mason has argues that Labour should abandon its traditional base in the white working class and the trades union movement, and look to creating a new progressive alliance, or ldquopopular front, with LGBT and BAME groups, and with other progressive political parties. Mason regards the SNP, unlike most other nationalist parties, as progressive and social democratic. On the eve of McDonnells Edinburgh interview Mason called infor ldquoa penalty-free independence referendum whenever Holyrood chooses.Im not saying that Paul Mason is writing Labour policy. Far from it. Many in the party regard him with suspicion, not least for appearing to abandon the working class. But it looks asthe Labour leadership has finally been persuaded that the SNP is not just a band of ldquotartan Tories, and that Jeremy Corbyn could do business with Nicola Sturgeon.Scottish Labour is anyway likely to be crushed again in the forthcoming General Wlection, while the SNP is in line for around  Westminster seats according to the polls. Its support would almost certainly be requiredLabour is to try to form a government, and McDonnells intervention could be an attempt to prepare the ground. Theres been no love lost between Corbyn and the mostly Blairite rump of the Scottish Labour Party, so he probably regards them as expendable.Not that Labour is admitting any of this. Indeed, the line from McDonnell in Edinburgh, echoed by the Shadow Business Secretary, Rebecca Long-Bailey on Newsnight, is that Labour will not form any ldquocoalitions or pacts with anyone. Labour is still smarting from those Tory election posters in  which showed the then leader, Ed Miliband, in Alex Salmonds breast pocket. It is imperative for Labour, in England at least, to deny any hint of an alliance with the SNP.But Scotland is a dferent. A ing Labour government in Westminster would require the tacit assistance of the SNP, perhaps on a confidence and supply basis. At any rate, the UK party leadership seems to have decided that offering a referendum is a risk worth taking to help some future co-operation to happen. This is huge development and raises questions about whether Labour can still be called a Unionist party.Paul Hutcheon: the biggest threat to the Union is Scottish Labours disintegrationLast week felt asa dam has broken. After three years in which Scottish politics has been in suspended animation, suddenly everyone was talking about independence again. Even Conservative commentators like The Times Iain Martin are now calling for a referendum in five years. s Simon Jenkins believes independence itself is now unavoidable, and called on Westminster to plan for it now.Of course, a referendum may not deliver a Yes. The polls still show Scotland split down the middle on independence. But this is a vindication of Nicola Sturgeons cautious, constitutional approach to winning independence. It is a blow to her critics, who had been calling for an unauthorised referendum, or even UDI. The former SNP MP, George Kerevan, had been calling for mass civil disobedience to obstruct London transport. But this is a blow her internal critics will be happy to take for there is now a real possibility of a referendum in the next couple of years.That isLabour manages to defeat Boris Johnson ndash a big ask, perhaps, but far from impossible. There will likely be a vote of no confidence the Tory PM next month, and he will almost certainly lose. If Labour fails to form an alternative government in  days, then Johnson has to call a General Election. Hes hoping to delay polling day until after Brexit on October . But that is a risky tactic. Such constitutional jiggery pokery could easily alienate voters, many of whom are anyway unconvinced by Johnsons abilities.Just about anything could happen in the next few weeks. But what is not in doubt is that Scottish independence, or at least a referendum, is back on the agenda. And almost exactly five years since the last one.

title: revealed-uk-shoppers-want-39-perfect-39-community-high-street
story: In a land of strip malls, edge-of-town supermarkets and soulless retail parks, shoppers still dream of traditional mom and pop stores.A survey , adults has found a real community shopping street should have baker, a butcher, a barber, post office, and hardware store.And even in an era of downloads, those surveyed said they would want a record shop.So we all know want makes the perfect high street. But where can we find them Well, forty are now vying to be officially named the best in Britain - based on their shopping experience and community initiatives.In Scotland, Turrf and Alness High Street are in the running alongside Prestwick Main Street, while Wales has Narbeth, Treorchy and Swansea High Streets under consideration.English high streets shortlisted in the Champion High Street Category are Hitchin Town Centre, Freeman Street in Grimsby and Belper in Derbyshire.For Northern Irish shoppers, Newtownards High Street, Enniskillen Town Centre and Bow Street, Lisburn, are up for the prize.The eventual winner will be required to demonstrate their commitment to their local community, great customer experience, an environmental mindset and innovative approach to retail.Judges will also visit each destination on the shortlist, to get a feel for its personality and general ambience.The winning street will be awarded the coveted Great British High Street  trophy, and a pound, cash prize to put towards a local high street initiative.The announcement follows research commissioned by Visa, in partnership with the Great British High Street demonstrating the positive impact the local high street has on communities.Seven in  consumers say shopping locally makes them feel happier, compared to shopping online or at a shopping centre - the main reason being that they know where their money is going.Half of consumers also feel their high street gives them a sense of pride in their local community.Spending time with friends and familyand offering a sense of communitywere other reasons cited for why high streets make people happier.After a rigorous selection process,  high streets from the South East of England to the Scottish Highlands have been shortlisted in the Champion High Street category, which recognises the nationrsquos best high streets.Additionally,  high streets have been shortlisted in the Rising Star category, identying those which are taking the lead to adapt and ersy.Sundeep Kaur, head of UK  Ireland merchant services at Visa, said: ldquoWersquove seen some fantastic entries for this yearrsquos Great British High Street Awards across both the Champion High Street and Rising Star categories.ldquoIn particular, the desire to innovate stands out among this yearrsquos entries, with high streets adapting to the challenges presented by a rapidly changing retail environment to find ways to thrive at a local level.ldquoAs our research shows, high streets play a vital role at the heart of communities, so this is a great opportunity for those communities with shortlisted high streets to show their support by placing their votes on the Great British High Street website.Last yearrsquos winner was Crickhowell High Street in Wales, located in a bustling rural town nestled in the Usk Valley on the edge of the Brecon BeaconsIt was commended for its community-led initiatives and strong network of independent businesses.High Streets Minister Jake Berry MP said: ldquoCongratulations to the shortlisted nominees for this yearrsquos Great British High Street Awards ndash the quality of the entries this year has been fantastic.ldquoHigh thriving for generations to come.ldquoInspiring high streets like these will play a key role in the Governmentrsquos vision to boost local growth and level up our regions.Out-of-town malls and online shopping have decimated community high streets. But this week Doug Gurr, UK boss of Amazon, the worlds biggest internet vendor, insisted physical retail ndash which is  per cent of UK shopping by value ndash was working hand-in-hand with e-commerce working to drive growth.Shortlisted high streets ndash Champion High Street categoryEngland. title: issue-day-comic-con-scotland
story: When is it taking place The Royal Highland Centre in Ingliston, Edinburgh, on October  and .So who will be there For such a young event, itrsquos proving to be a big draw - top of the bill this year is Belgian action hero Jean Claude Van Damme, star of movies such as Kickboxer, Street Fighter and The Expendables .And you can buy the lsquoPlatinum JCVD Experience rsquoYou sure can - for a tidy pound,  people can have a ldquounique once in a letime experience.For that price, you receive a package that includes a signed photograph in a commemorative frame, a professional photo with the -year-old actor and tickets to an intimate talk about his le and career, after which he will do a ldquomeet and greet around the audience, which is limited to only  people. title: gold-rush-commercial-goldmine-set-running-december
story: But gold-mining is about to become a reality for a firm in Tyndrum, Argyll, after it received the necessary funding to buy the excavation equipment needed to start work at the site.Scotgold Resources has been working to reopen an abandoned gold mine in Cononish for  years and claims it will now be able to begin commercial gold production later this year.If successful, this will be the first time in decades that the precious metal has been mined in Scotland.Richard Gray, managing director and CEO at Scotgold, said he believes the the project will ldquoprovide a signicant boost to the local economy around Tyndrum.In the latest raft of funding for the firm, finance provider Simply has loaned the project pound,, which has been used to purchase equipment including an excavator, a loading shovel and a dumper.It is hoped that this will give the firm the last push it needs to be fully operational by the end of the year.Ross Pickburn, regional sales manager at Simply, said: ldquoThis was an incredibly interesting deal to work on, not least because it was the first gold mine Irsquod ever helped fund.ldquoItrsquos great working with a company that produces Scottish gold and a team that is creating jobs in the area.ldquoWe got to know about the needs of the company and were able to structure a deal that worked for all parties.Scotgold acquired the Cononish site in  and has embarked on a long journey to bring the mine up to a workable state and start producing gold.Planning permission for the project has been agreed, subject to certain conditions, by Loch Lomond and Trossachs National Park Authority, while the business also recently renegotiated and extended a secured loan deal with Nat le Roux, its chairman and ldquomajor shareholder.The loan facility from Mr le Roux, who is a former chief executive of the IG Group, is said to have increased by up to poundm to poundm.At one point Scotgold predicted that gold and silver production at the site could reach as much as pound million per year over a seven-year lespan.However, this has changed over time due to fluctuations in the price of gold.Experts think there could be as much as five tonnes of gold to be found in the hills near Tyndrum, encased in quartz which must be dug out and crushed.Up to , ounces of precious metals could be mined per year, and the project could create around  jobs for local people.Villagers in nearby Tyndrum, a popular stop on the route north to Glencoe and Fort William, hope to open a visitors centre and market Cononish gold to tourists.Scotgold produced its first gold from Cononish several years ago during a bulk ore processing trial at the site.It was later sold for an average of pound, per ounce, a more than three-fold premium on the average gold price of the day.The mineral was sold in the form of ldquorounds minted by Baird and Co Bullion Merchants.The first round, embossed, like all the coins, with a stagrsquos head, was snapped up by Graham Donaldson, a Scotgold shareholder who lives in Christchurch, Dorset.His bid of pound,.p was the highest.At the time of the sale, he said: ldquoAs to what I would do with it now, I would probably look at it and stroke it, and put it in a safe.Mr Donaldson said he and his we planned in time to get new engagement and wedding rings made from Cononish gold, to replace the budget rings they bought when they married.ldquoThose are worn thin, he added.Scotgold, which also has offices in West Perth, Australia, believes its gold will attract a premium price as a niche product for tourists, jewellers and couples keen on Scottish gold wedding or engagement rings.The firm also previously announced it had struck a deal with a prominent jeweller to manufacture the first items made from Scottish gold.Exploration work in another area - the Grampian gold project - is also continuing, with a view to potentially developing sites in the Ochils, Glen Orchy, Glen Lyon, Inverliever and Knapdale under Crown Estate ldquooption agreements.

title: bothies-get-21st-century-makeover
story: Created in the main from estate buildings built for stalking parties or gamkeepers, bothies provide basic but generally wind and watertight accommodation in remote locations which are left unlocked for anyone to use and have become popular with hillwalkers and climbers.Scattered throughout the wilder parts of Scotland, England and Wales they are the shepherdsrsquo cottages, huts and similar buildings many of which in the normal course of events might be allowed to fall derelict.Very few are less than a century old and the ravages of time, climate and remoteness makes maintenance a challenge.Now it has emerged that in a bid to make them fit for the st century, a record amount has been spent to get them into shape.Repairs and updates to the tune of pound, have been made over a year to continue to offer a safe place for climbers out in the mountains.The Mountain Bothy Association was founded  years ago by Bernard Heath after he spotted a remark in the visitor book at the Backhill of the Bush bothy in Galloway Forest park, suggesting the setting up of a club to save a growing number of deserted farm buildings from ruin.He felt a collective effort was needed to keep the abandoned cottages and huts weatherproof in order ldquoto maintain simple shelters in remote country for the use and benefit of all who love wild and lonely places.The charity now runs over  bothies across the UK with the vast majority being in Scotland. They obtain the ownersrsquo permission to maintain buildings as bothies and to make them available as open shelters.MBA volunteers are tasked with visiting the buildings to look for any structural faults or cosmetic issues that need fixing or more fundamental renovation. And it is the volunteers that carry out the restoration and maintenance work which is financed by member subscriptions and by donations.The charity revealed that their latest annual spending on the bothies has risen by % and expect that the expenditure will not stop there.Neil Stewart of the MBA said: "We now look after  bothies plus two emergency mountain shelters throughout Scotland, Wales and northern England."Through membership fees and generous donations we managed to spend a record sum of pound, on bothy maintenance in  and managed to increase our membership to over , - an increase of %."These buildings are however in remote areas and subject to the worst ravages of the weather so ongoing repair and maintenance is required. We look forward to continuing our efforts in years to come to provide open shelters in remote country for use by outdoor enthusiasts."Its biggest task in  was taking over the Garbh Choire refuge hut deep in the Cairngorms National Park and doing extensive work to bring it into use as part of the scheme.Among the projects was a former schoolhouse at Duag Bridge in the northern Highlands, which had declined to a state of dereliction, which was taken on as a new bothy by the association and fully renovated.Camban bothy in the western Highlands, which has been an MBA-maintained building for  years, was given another major renovation with volunteers undertaking work over a number of weeks.Concerns over bats delayed progress in getting Willrsquos Bothy in working order in southern Scotland, but the MBA say they still hope to have work completed this year.In its latest annual report for  the trustees of the MBA said: "The Association believes it has a duty to care for the quality of the experience enjoyed by those who visit bothies, and to ensure that all those who are involved in outdoor recreation understand the fragile nature of this resource, and the impact their behaviour can have on the bothy and its environment."In general, the work of the association continues to be a success. We are achieving our objective in maintaining simple shelters in remote country for the use and benefit of all who love wild and lonely places."A bothy would not normally be connected to the public utilities, and any amenities provided would be of a very basic standard.In areas there is an appreciable fire hazard, or limited fuel, existing fireplaces may be replaced by a stove.The increase in spending comes a month after a bid was being being made to stamp out antisocial behaviour, vandalism and fire-raising at remote bothies in southern Scotland.Police said they wanted to ensure the shelters were "used for the purpose they are intended for".In one recent incident a group of hillwalkers was denied access by a "bothy full of revellers" and later had to be rescued off a hillside.Bothy Watch aims to raise awareness and keep the buildings free from damage.A wide range of groups including Forestry and Land Scotland, the Mountain Bothies Association , local authorities and mountain rescue team volunteers are involved in the initiative.

title: cultural-sports-attendances-soar-glasgow
story: In the  years since the organisationrsquos creation, attendances have increased by . million, from . million in the first year to . million last year.Kelvingrove and Riverside museums attracted more than . million visitors each, while Glasgow Club facilities welcomed attendance figures of around . million.There were . million recorded visits to the cityrsquos  libraries, including The Mitchell, while music venues such as Glasgow Royal Concert Hall, City Halls, Old Fruitmarket and the Kelvingrove Bandstand attracted more than , customers.:Harry Potter route still waiting for ScotRails scenic trainsCouncillor David McDonald, Glasgow Le chair, said: ldquoWe deliver for the people of Glasgow and thanks to our incredible staff and volunteers we are changing lives for the better.ldquoMore people are getting fit and physically active more people are engaging with, and enjoying, our cultural assets more people are benefitting from services which are rooted in, and valued by, their local communities.ldquoGlasgow is home to iconic cultural and sporting venues, world-class events and community facilities which make a dference each and every day.ldquoTo achieve record-breaking attendances of almost  million in the last year is testament to that success.:An updated guide to Scotland - with a distinctly Outlander themeOther events which boosted the figures include the inaugural Glasgow  European Championships, Celtic Connections and World Pipe Band Championships.Dr Bridget McConnell CBE, Glasgow Le chief executive, said: ldquoWersquove enjoyed another exceptional year.ldquoFrom stand-out events such as the  European Championships, to bringing Dippy the dinosaur to Kelvingrove, wersquove worked to provide opportunities which touch the lives of citizens and visitors alike.ldquoOn the global stage we excel, but in our communities, the work we do changes lives. Our staff and volunteers are always on hand.

title: west-highland-way-even-harder-negotiate
story: The -mile West Highland Way has always been a tough trek, even for seasoned walkers.But now, thanks to wave after wave of alternating torrential rain and glorious sunshine, the path is almost impassable.The Way is just one victim of an astonishing growth spurt that has turned Scotland even greener than usual ndash with some farmers saying their grass is growing faster than cows can eat it.Some hikers on the lush and less populated eastern bank of Loch Lomond have decided to stray off The Way and follow the narrow lochside road instead, at least as far as it goes.Impenetrable ferns, nettles and shrubs, fuelled by the warm, humid air, have bolted up along the sides of the path.A spokesman for Stirlingshire Council, one of the local authorities The Way passes through, explained: ldquoThe combination of warm weather and sporadic bursts of heavy rain witnessed this summer, and in previous years, is the perfect catalyst for the rapid growth of a range of weeds and excess foliage over a short period of time.ldquoThis is particularly true for areas close to water, such as river banks, and will be keenly felt in parts of the West Highland Way, which will go largely untouched for most of the year.It is up to landowners to maintain The Way, but walking enthusiasts admit it is far from easy to keep up with the kind of growth Scotland is experiencing as our summers, on average, become warmer and wetter thanks to climate change.:Anger over secret justice for skippers who break fishing lawsA Stirling Council spokesman added: ldquoThe West Highland Way is a core path, meaning responding to safety concerns on the route and responsibility for maintaining overgrown foliage resides with inidual land owners.ldquoThe bulk of the West Highland Way crosses through private land and we would encourage anyone who has encountered problems on the route to raise this through either the relevant local authority, or the West Highland Way management group.ldquoWhen areas of concern are highlighted to Stirling Council at the group or by the public, we will either contact the relevant landowners or undertake improvements.ldquoStirling Councilrsquos Access Team is currently working in the Carbeth and Strathblane area to improve access there, and we continually monitor the growth of foliage across the council estate throughout the year.Stirlingshire has been hit by dramatic growth in recent weeks, including of giant hogweed, the invasive species now blighting riverbanks and railway lines across Scotland.The growth spurt, according to gardeners, has brought more weeds and more pests. Jackie McMaster, who is the gardening co-ordinator for the City Works course at Glasgow City College, helps run a roof garden.She said: ldquoThis year the slugs are big enough to saddle up and ride around! Ferns are prolic and lots of stuff has bolted. Other produce is just starting to come now. Quite a weird year so far. Last summer Scotland also had record high temperatures, but less rain and a poor harvest. There were concerns about scarcity of water right through the spring.This year ndash so far ndash farmers are delighted. One, in Lothian, said the grass was growing faster than his cows could eat it.A spokesman for the National Union of Farmers said: ldquoThe good weather this year has provided some blessed relief from ongoing Brexit worries.ldquoIn stark contrast to last year ndash when we had the extreme heat but no moisture ndash the combination of warm temperatures and plenty of rain have made for near ideal growing conditions in many parts of the country.ldquoThere is an abundance of grass for livestock, some high-quality stocks of silage and hay have been made and harvest has already started around the country, several days earlier than in . There is tremendous potential for a good cereal harvest and a decent dry spell in the coming weeks will see combines rolling in most parts of Scotland.ldquoAnd the weather has also been a win, win for our soft fruit growers ndash lots of sweet, tasty fruit and great demand for Scottish berries.

title: labour-msps-urge-leonard-stand-uk-leadership
story: The Scottish leader will face his rebellious Holyrood group at the partyrsquos Glasgow HQ as he tries to show he still retains a modicum of authority.A party source said: ldquoThis is going to be a tense meeting and MSPs will plead for Richard and his team to stand up to the Corbyn Project and dissuade them from writing off Scottish Labour.ldquoTherersquos a great deal of distress within the group about the partyrsquos future, but the biggest concern is what the cost of this could be for the future of the UK.:Labours Tom Watson: Scottish indyref is not the answerAnother predicted MSPs would ldquolet off steam, but that, as in other meetings led by Mr Leonard, the party would not decide on any specic course of action.Mr Leonard was humiliated last week after Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell unilaterally rewrote Scottish Labour policy on another independence vote at the Edinburgh Fringe.Despite Mr Leonard saying in March that a UK Labour government would refuse to allow Indyref, evenHolyrood demanded it, Mr McDonnell twice said that was not the case.ldquoThatrsquos up to the Scottish people and the Scottish Parliament. Irsquom not into blocking democratic exercises by any means, he said, adding Jeremy Corbyn thought so too.With a general election likely soon, the comment was seen as extending an olive branch to Nicola Sturgeon in case SNP MPs are needed to sustain a minority Labour government at Westminster.The First Minister yesterday said it was ldquoa refreshing change to Mr McDonnell ldquorecognise and accept that it is the Scottish Parliament and people who should decide on Indyref.But Mr McDonnellrsquos intervention unleashed a wave of party infighting, with most Labour MSPs saying they ldquodeplore any attempts to undermine Scottish Labourrsquos position.They said on Thursday: ldquoWe are clear Labourrsquos position on Scotlandrsquos future is a decision for Scottish Labour, which the UK party must accept.In a further blow to Mr Leonardrsquos standing, it then emerged the statement was issued against his express wishes by the chair of Labour MSPs, Jackie Baillie.Mr Leonard, a strong supporter of Mr Corbyn who has failed to repeat his March position since Mr McDonnellrsquos comments, had wanted to avoid a confrontation with London.On Friday, Scottish Labour general secretary Brian Roy quit with immediate effect, amid reports he had been ousted as Mr Corbynrsquos office takes greater control of the Scottish operation.Mr Leonard, who has been leader since November , was also reported to have lost confidence in Mr Roy after Scottish Labour crashed to  per cent of the vote in Mayrsquos European election.Although todayrsquos ldquoaway-day in Glasgow was arranged long before the current crisis, MSPs are expected to use it to push Mr Leonard not to let Scottish Labour regain its ldquobranch office tag.The Scottish partyrsquos precarious finances, and its reliance on London for cash, are also expected to come up.:Most people in UK would grant second referendum by , poll findsSources said MSPs were mainly angry at the UK leadership, not Mr Leonard, but he still had to get on the front foot.One MSP said the ldquoclumsiness and disregard with which Mr McDonnell had treated the Scottish party was as bad as his message on the Union.There is also renewed focus on Lesley Laird, the Shadow Scottish Secretary, who as a member of the shadow cabinet should take the same line as Mr McDonnell, but as Mr Leonardrsquos deputy would also be expected to take the same stand as the Scottish leader.Labour peer Lord Foulkes, a former MSP, yesterday admitted he had told Ms Laird to her face that he thought ldquoalmost anyone would be better than her.SNP MSP Keith Brown said: ldquoScottish Labour are an utter shambles. Voters can see theyrsquore out of ideas. Their credibility is in tatters, and Labour members must despair at the lack of leadership in standing up to the Tories.ldquoIf Labour want to stand a chance of recovery, they need to start standing up for the interests of the Scottish people ndash against Brexit, and for Scotland taking its future into its own hands.Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson said Mr McDonnellrsquos action been ldquothe political equivalent of a drive-by shooting, except that he had ldquoreversed the car to have another go.

title: worried-families-stockpile-4bn-goods-no-deal
story: A survey by finance provider Premium Credit found one in five people had begun hoarding, with the average spend around pound each.The survey estimated around , people had spent more than pound, on stockpiling in light of Boris Johnson ldquodo or die promise to leave the EU by October .The government and the grocery industry predict short-term supply problems in the event of no-deal.Of those stockpiling, % bought extra food, % extra medicine for themselves, % bought spare drinks and % had bought extra medicine for other family members.The report also found Brexit-related stockpiling was also hitting business cash flow, as companies took out credit to cover the cost of insurance and other fixed costs.Adam Morghem, at Premium Credit, said: ldquoOver the past three months we have seen an increase in clients looking to use premium finance to pay for their insurance, and we believe a key factor behind this is the impact of stockpiling on cash flows, forcing more businesses and households to spread the cost of their insurance.Similar research in the weeks leading up to the original Brexit deadline found around  per cent of the country had spent pound.bn stockpiling ahead of March .The former cabinet minister Lord Heseltine, who lost the Tory whip for voting LibDem in the Euro election, yesterday warned it would be ldquoan intolerable position for democracyMr Johnson forced through no-deal without Westminsterrsquos consent.On Skyrsquos Sophy Ridge programme, he also took a swipe at Dominic Cummings, Mr Johnsonrsquos top aide, who he described in an article in the Sunday Times as a ldquoself-styled revolutionary menace.ldquoIt is absolutely central that parliament should be able to call to account people who represent them as ministers, and at the moment wersquore being told by a particular figure, whorsquos proud of it, that hersquos more or less running the show.In their joint article, Lord Heseltine and former Commons speaker Baroness Boothroyd, warned the Prime Minister not to ldquorip the heart out of out democracy and subvert our parliament.Policing minister Kit Malthouse told Sky: ldquoObviously, therersquos a lot of hyperbole being thrown about as we approach the date of  October.ldquoIn the end, even people like Lord Heseltine, great figures from the past, who have never quite reconciled themselves to the idea that wersquore going to leave the European Union, are going to have to focus on the fact that thatrsquos what the British people commanded us to do, and thatrsquos what the government is committing to do at the end of October.Looking ahead to a meeting between Taoiseach Leo Varadkar and Mr Johnson next month, the Irish government last night insisted the border backstop would not be up for renegotiation.Despite Mr Johnson making abolition of the backstop a precondition for talks with the EU, Dublin stressed changes to the Withdrawal Agreement would not be countenanced.A spokesman for the Taoiseach said on Sunday: ldquoThe Taoiseach has invited the British Prime Minister to Dublin for talks on Northern Ireland and Brexit.ldquoTheir offices are in contact to agree a date for these talks in the coming weeks.ldquoSuch a meeting would give both sides an opportunity to gain a better understanding of their respective positions.ldquoAs has repeatedly been made clear, the Withdrawal Agreement and the backstop are not up for negotiation.ldquoAny discussions on changes to the Political Declaration would occur between the UK and the EU.

title: green-mp-says-all-female-cabinet-avoid-no-deal
story: She made the offer to Nicola Sturgeon, LibDem leader Jo Swinson, Plaid Cymrursquos Liz Saville Robert, Tory Justine Greening, Change UKrsquos Anna Soubry, Independent MP Heidi Allen and others reported the Brighton MP saying a cabinet of women from across the political spectrum would ldquowork for reconciliation rather than fight new political battles.She said: ldquoWhy women  Because I believe women have shown they can bring a dferent perspective to crises, are able to reach out to those they disagree with and cooperate to find solutions.Ms Allen said: ldquoWomen are by nature less tribal, so Irsquom very willing to play my part and try.But Ms Soubry said ldquoIf yoursquore trying to stop no-deal Brexit then the key thing is to bring people together, not to ide them on the basis of gender.Shadow home secretary Diane Abbott tweeted that a national government ldquodidnrsquot work for Ramsey Mcdonald [sic] and wonrsquot work now, whatever the gender of participants.Tory MP James Cleverly added: ldquoYou didnrsquot try voting for the deal though did you  When you say lsquotry everythingrsquo do you mean lsquotry everything, except the one thing guaranteed to prevented a no-deal Brexitrsquo, ie leaving with a deal

title: highland-eco-centre-learns-past-survive-future
story: The Shieling Project at Struy near Beauly was founded by Dr Sam Harrison, who has a background in working with at-risk young people and developing environmental learning programmes for schools.In the Highlands and Western Isles, every summer would see women and children migrating to higher land with the cattle for summer grazing. There they would live in simple huts, shielings, making butter and cheese, with the younger generation learning about themselves and their heritage from the elders.:It is exactly that spirit of community and transmission of customs that Dr Harrison and partner Karen Marshall, who runs the projectrsquos outdoor nursery, are working so hard to maintain.The Shieling Project was dreamed up  years ago when Dr Harrison, who at the time was a nomadic educator, travelling from school to school helping children paint a ldquopicture of the richness of where they lived.He dreamed of having a permanent site where he could rear livestock and teach people the value of working with, and for, nature. It was during the study of his PhD in Place Based Education that the idea began to crystallise.He said: ldquoI was thinking about the shieling as a way of educating kids because thatrsquos how they learned about the wider natural landscape. In the old days, they went up to the shieling, they found about all the place names and all the plants and animals out there.ldquoI loved the idea of kids being in the outdoors, running around the hills, learning about them, looking after the cows, fending off the wolves, singing all the songs around the fireplace.ldquoEventually, I just kind got to a stage where I had no choice but to start.Six years on and the project now has  employees who welcome school and private groups to pitch in while learning lost skills.The project represents the value of how communities used to live. Dr Harrison said: ldquoItrsquos a reminder that we managed to live for a very long time in a sustainable way. There were more people living off the land who were were self sufficient.Careful not to romanticise what would have been a hard le, Dr Harrison believes modern societies would only benefit from reconnecting with the wild.He said: ldquoI think nowadays when we think about environmental issues, we just think humans are bad but the Shieling is giving children a story that people arenrsquot inherently bad but were part of a healthy eco-system.ldquoThe Shieling is a little tradition that has got a big message about what wersquore struggling with today about sustainable communities.Children, young people and adults come to the project to learn how to tend to animals, grow food, cook and turn off their devices to collaboratively create a culture for themselves through songs, storytelling and film.Guests help construct low carbon buildings and monitor the energy they are using while on site.:Dr Harrison said: ldquoTypically environmental education has been disaster education. How rubbish everything is, attempting to motivate change by guilt and shame. Here, and especially for children, we think that a stronger motivation is love, enjoyment, care for a place.ldquoHere we let people experience a bit of off grid living and be outside for long periods of time. All this adds up to skills for a sustainable future, but it also adds up to fun, to a sense of mental and physical well-being.Dr Harrison hopes that visitors might then see any changes they need to make to adapt to and mitigate climate change as positive.He said: ldquoIn terms of educating children like this, the idea is that we try and use practical experiences so wersquore getting peoplersquos bodies and minds engaged, because most of schooling is either sitting being told stuff or is virtual and itrsquos not engaging peoplersquos bodies and hearts, as well as their minds.It is during the practical experiences of making a basket or digging up peat or feeding calves where young people can think through the ideas they are being taught and ldquolive through some of the big questions being asked.Dr Harrison said: ldquoYou canrsquot ask a child what a stable future looks like and expect an answer in a minute. They need weeks or years or lives to think about that. And they also need to experience it, rather than just have it as an abstract thing, because thatrsquos the problem with all these big things like climate change, sustainability, and bioersity, theyrsquore so huge. How do you get hold of it  How do you understand it  How do you make it real in a way that you can hold on to and do something about it ldquoOtherwise, itrsquos just like, lsquooh, Irsquom scared about thatrsquo, because itrsquos just an idea.The untraditional gender politics of the historical shielings is another teaching arm of Dr Harrisonrsquos programme. While the men remained in the low lands with the burgeoning crops, the women took the cattle, and therefore all the wealth, up to graze.He said: ldquoThat alone was fairly unusual in some of these traditional cultures where the men tend to be fairly entrenched in their power positions.Children are ldquowonderfully resilient, and flexible and open to new ideas but are not able to make the choices about how they live and what they do.Dr Harrison said: ldquoWhat wersquore trying to do is show that sustainability is a way of being happier and healthier and having fun.ldquoWe want them to see that we can build up build some of our buildings, we can grow some of our food, we can take our entertainment, art, and cultural experience back into our own control and do it ourselves. We can actually have a feeling that wersquore involved in our landscape and our community.The beauty of the project is that it looks both backwards and forwards to inform its teachings.Dr Harrison said: ldquoWersquore asking what the future is going to look like, and what does that mean to you.

title: letters-working-class-solidarity-not-end-borders
story: In  Labour, the Liberal Democrats, the STUC, the Scottish churches and civic Scotland agreed the Claim of Right which asserted the sovereignty of Scotland within the UK. It stated that the signatories acknowledge the sovereign right of the Scottish people to determine the form of government best suited to their needs and do hereby declare and pledge that in all our actions and deliberations their interests shall be paramount. The Claim of Right was launched at a historic ceremony in the General Assembly Hall in Edinburgh. I attended as Vice -Chairman of the Scottish Labour Party. It was signed by every Labour and Liberal Democrat MP who were currently serving, including Gordon Brown and Alistair Darling, except Tam Dalyell. The Claim of Right was the genesis for the  Scotland Referendum which led to the re-establishment of the Scottish Parliament. The Claim of Rights was endorsed by the Annual Conference of the Scottish Labour Party and this position has never been rescinded.This does not mean that Scottish Labour cannot campaign against independence in a referendum as they did in , supporting the status quo or some form of devo max. However, I agree with our former First Minister, Henry McLeish that Scottish Labour must have positive and radical policies for a new constitutional settlement.Richard Leonard passionately argues that the problems and solutions for working people are class-related and not those of national identity. He is right. But where and at what level those class solutions are applied are for voters to decide on tactical and other considerations. Working-class solidarity does not and never has ended at borders.There is also a lot of hypocrisy from Labour MPs and MSPs who support a second referendum on Brexit but oppose a second referendum on independence, the democratic principles are the same.I am a long-time supporter of devolution of power not just to the countries and regions of Britain but to communities. Our unwritten constitution is in desperate need of reform, a fairer voting system, abolition of the unelected House of Lords, an elected head of state with specied powers to hold ministers to account, and much more.Bob Thomson, Past chairman treasurer, Scottish Labour Party, Glasgow G.AS a "tribal" Labour voter who may never vote Labour again, could I suggest to Jeremy Corbyn, John McDonnell, Diane Abbott, et al that they should consider leaving and, instead, take over an obscure student union somewhere far away and play their infantile games there, as this is clearly their level. This would allow the grown-ups a chance to revive a once-great party and provide a credible challenge to one of the worst governments in living history.Jim White, Glasgow G.REGARDING the many letters you have published over recent days about the increasing woes of the Labour Party, I note that they iniably refer to "Scottish Labour" or even the "Scottish Labour Party", but according to the Electoral Commission, Labour in Scotland is registered merely as an accounting unit of the UK Labour Party.It is hard to whip up enthusiasm for an accounting unit, and as Richard Leonard sits Miss Haversham-like in his branch office,amid the ruins of his expectations, he should admit thathe and his members have no aspirations for their Scottish accounting unit it is hardly surprising they have no aspirations for Scotland.Ruth Marr, Stirling.THE SNP would like Scotland to leave the UK but remain in the EU. However,Scotland left the UK, before or after the UK left the EU, then Scotland would be both outside the EU and outside the UK.Most people would agree that for Scotland to prosper it must agree trading terms with both the rUK and the EU, possibly becoming an EU member state. I am told by nationalists that the UK Government does not care about Scottish interests. Nationalists portray Westminster as the villain. Irsquom then puzzled by the seemingly contradictory idea that somehow Westminster would be better disposed towards Scotlandit were to become independent. I would have thought a separate rUK would put its own interests first and at the expense of Scotlandrsquos. While Irsquom sure Scotland could become an EU member, the terms of its joining are not decided by the people or the Government of Scotland, it would be on EU terms.Outside both the UK and EU, Scotland would need to find secure trading partners and make trade agreements quickly. This is also the weakness in Brexit it is not a strong negotiating position, even for a large country. The argument that Scotland has great natural assets that other countries will compromise their interests over is simply wrong. Except for niche brand luxury products, for example whisky, there is nothing that can be found in Scotland that cannot be sourced, cheaper and in greater quantity where, this includes financial services, energy, petrochemicals, timber and food.I suggest it would be a serious mistake to leave the UK, eventhe UK leaves the EU. There is little to be gained from compounding the current Brexit situation. If Scotland left the UK I think many people would be disappointed with the result.James Reilly, Turrf.CHRISTINE Grahame, SNP MSP , displays selective memory loss. She should try to remember, had we voted Yes in  we would be out of both the UK and EU by now. We voted to stay part of the UK in the full knowledge there was to be a later UK-wide vote to remain or leave the EU.This was not a four-part membership of the EU so collectively the UK voted Leave. Alex Salmond and Nicola Sturgeon were quite happy to drag Scotland out and Leave both unions.Scotlandrsquos votes in several previous General elections have determined what colour of government sat in Westminster without feigned outrage from the losing voters in England. You canrsquot always get what you want, that is democracy at work. To use the SNPrsquos own warped logic, the Kingdom of Fe, Orkney and Shetland Isles, and the Lord of theIsles could all cry ldquoFreedom and demand independence.Allan Thompson, Bearsden.

title: mark-smith-wings-scotland-party-good-idea-theory-just-look-ways-turn-yes-no
story: Anyway, the more important question is: how seriously should we take his theory, which is that a new party could maximise the pro-independence vote at the next Scottish election  Mr Campbell thinks the new party may be necessary because he knows therersquos a risk the  vote wonrsquot produce an independence-supporting majority. And so, hersquos thinking a new pro-yes party could bring in more regional list votes for the cause.On the face of it, the theory seems sound. The Holyrood electoral system was set up with the aim of making it dficult for any one party to get a majority which means a party that performs well in the first-past-the-post seats will find it harder to make gains on the regional lists.:Jim Sillars: Wings over Scotland plan for a new party could "split" pro-indy voteYou can see this from the last election. The SNP did well in the list vote, but because it also did well on first-past-the-post, it was the other, mainly unionist parties that picked up the list MSPs. Mr Campbellrsquos idea is that a Wings party could change this by taking some of the list votes that are being ldquowasted on the SNP, therefore increasing the chances of a Yes majority.But the theory has over-looked two important factors. First, the SNP wonrsquot stand for it. At the last election, they ran a ldquoBoth votes SNP campaign based on the theory thatthey lost some first-past-the-post seats, they could pick up seats on the regional list ndash and that was despite the fact there were other pro-independence parties standing on the list, such as Rise and the Greens. Adding another party based on Wings is not going to change that.Second, Mr Campbellrsquos theory is based on the idea the SNP will broadly retain the number of first-past-the-post seats they have at the moment, but thatrsquos far from certain. Whether we like it or not, the next Scottish election will be fought on a single issue ndash whether the pro-Yes parties should be given a majority to demand another referendum ndash and in that scenario many,not most, supporters of the union will vote tactically against the SNP, and that means the party could lose some first-past-the-post seats. Combined with losing list votes to Wings, this could put a pro-independence majority at risk.There are also particular problems with a party based on the Wings brand, the main one being its aggressive image. Mr Campbellrsquos traditional response to this has effectively been ldquochill, itrsquos just banter but the SNP leadership knows the more aggressive nationalists have damaged the cause in the past and a party based on Wings would only heighten the problem. Yes, any Wings party would only be an outer limb of the Yes movement, but political poison could spread quickly through the bloodstream.:Labours Tom Watson: Scottish indyref is not the answerThe Wings party would also do something  damaging: it would draw attention to the dis-satisfaction within the Yes movement ndash indeed, the ision appears to be one of the reasons Mr Campbell is considering starting up the party in the first place.In his blog discussing the idea for example, Mr Campbell said SNP supporters didnrsquot want to vote for ldquoextreme radical fringe parties like the Greens because they donrsquot want to ldquofill womenrsquos changing rooms and toilets with male rapists. This, of course, is a reference to his opposition to the proposals to allow trans people to identy their own gender, but itrsquos only one of the SNP policies he dislikes.You might say: who cares about these disagreements over policy as long as everyone agrees on the bigger aim of independence  But part of the success of the yes movement in  in growing so rapidly was that the dferent groupings more or less fell in behind Alex Salmond. A new Wings party, on the other hand, could provide a mouthpiece to those within the independence movement who are unhappy with Nicola Sturgeon over a range of issues: among them, trans rights, the timing of a second referendum, and the swing towards austerity, as some see it, that was signalled with the Growth Commission. If the yes movement is, and looks, ided ndash particularly over the economy ndash voters will fear a Brexit-style debacle and will be more likely to vote no.And, finally, we have the image problem: what would a Wings Over Scotland party actually look and sound like  Famously, David Cameron once dismissed UKIP as a bunch of fruitcakes, loonies and closet racists and therersquos a real danger that a Wings party would attract people from the extremities of the independence movement in a similar way.You know the ones I mean. The ones who are blatantly anti-English. The ones whose arms ache from waving saltires. The ones who believe Mr Campbell didnrsquot really lose the defamation case against Kezia Dugdale. And the ones who suggested that the women who accused Alex Salmond of sexual assault might have ldquothrown themselves at him. Presumably some of this bunch would stand for the Wings party and what a sight that would make.I appreciate, of course, that none of this may happen in the end, but the success Mr Campbell has made of his blog would suggest therersquos a decent chance of him making a success of a party too.The problem is that, in real politics, the megaphone hersquos been pointing at people who think like him will be turned on an entirely dferent audience: voters who need to be convinced therersquos a coherent, rational and calm plan for Scottish independence.Those kind of voters are unlikely to be impressed by Mr Campbellrsquos aggressive style. The problem for the SNP is that some nationalists might be.

title: teachers-strike-coatbridge-blue-water-schools-goes-ahead
story: Members of the NASUWT teaching union refuse toto the Buchanan and St Ambrose High School campus at Coatbridge, North Lanarkshire, until given advice by their lawyers.The Scottish Government ordered the investigation into the site after parents and teachers reported blue water coming from school taps, and raised fears of links between possible chemical exposure and illness among staff and pupils.:SNP MSPs accused of trying to "weaponise" blue water school rowThe report, published on Friday, concluded the schools are safe to attend and supported them reopening as scheduled at the start of the new term on Monday August .Pupils are due toon Wednesday, with teachers expected to start back two days earlier for in-service days.However,  NASUWT members are now on strike, planned to continue until September  unless they are satisfied the site poses no risks.The report found water samples from the campus pass all quality standards and the methane membrane under the school building was installed correctly, while no landfill related gases were detected.:Cancer-causing chemicals found in grounds at blue water schoolMore than  soil sample tests found contaminant levels were not of concern, apart from higher levels of polychlorinated biphenyls at one location.The review, co-led by public health consultant Dr Margaret Hannah, recommended North Lanarkshire Council complete a "full and independently veried removal of the chemical" as soon as possible.It also recommended publishing the results of regular drinking water tests at the campus and the setting up of a group of site users to allow any concerns to be raised.Chris Keates, NASUWT General Secretary, said: "The strike action at Buchanan and St Ambrose remains in place and will resume today as scheduled."Our experts and legal counsel are examining the site report and we are awaiting their advice on the next steps."We have also posed some interim questions to the council and we are waiting for answers to those."

title: brake-issues-caledonian-sleeper-caused-emergency-edinburgh-waverley
story: The RAIB raised their concerns over brake failure while launching an investigation into how the Lowland Sleeper sparked an emergency at Edinburgh Waverley station.The Rail Accident Investigation Branch said the northbound train eventually came to a halt, but over  yards beyond its intended stopping point.While there was no damage or any injuries as a result of the incident the RAIB said the outcome could "potentially have been worse, had it led to a collision with another train".Investigators say that on the approach to Edinburgh at .am on August , the driver discovered that the trains braking performance was "well below normal" and it "failed to stop as scheduled".An RAIB preliminary investigation indicated that he had no control of the brakes on the coaches because a brake pipe isolating valve was in the closed position when the train left Carstairs station.The RAIB said this meant that the only effective brakes on the train from London Eustonas it approached Edinburgh were those on the locomotive, which were "insufficient to maintain control of the train".The train was eventually brought to a standstill by the operation of an emergency device in one of the coaches by the train manager, which caused the train brakes to apply.The incident meant services to London, Dunbar, North Berwick and Tweedbank were cancelled or delayed, before the train was pushed back to the .The Caledonian Sleeper has suffered a number of setbacks since it relaunched with a new poundm fleet in April. On its first night, both north and southbound trains rolled into Glasgow and Euston hours behind schedule.The full Rail Accident Investigation Branch investigation "will identy the sequence of events that led to the incident".The inquiry will consider:* How the isolating valve came to be closed at Carstairs* The preparation of the train at Carstairs, including the attachment of the locomotive and testing of the trains brakes* How the train was driven* The suitability of relevant procedures and working practices* The design and approval of the brake system fitted to the Mark  coaches* Any relevant underlying management or organisational factors

title: sturgeon-backs-paid-leave-couples-miscarriage
story: The First Minister, who has revealed she suffered a miscarriage in , said it would help remove the ldquotaboo and stigma around it.New Zealand is looking at having three days of paid bereavement leave for women and their partners after a miscarriage or a stillbirth.New Zealanders are already entitled to leave after the death of family members or children.UK law currently entitles women who have a stillbirth after the th week of pregnancy to maternity leave and associated pay but not bereavement leave.Holyrood does not have the power to introduce miscarriage leave, as employment law is reserved to Westminster.However Ms Sturgeon said she would strongly support its introduction UK-wide.Asked about the New Zealand idea on ITVrsquos Loose Women, she said: ldquoI would support that. I feel really strongly about trying to remove the stigma around miscarriage. People feel itrsquos not something they can or should talk about.ldquoPeople donrsquot talk about being pregnant until after three months, and the whole implication of that is thatyou miscarry, itrsquos something you keep to yourself often.ldquoItrsquos really dficult. Itrsquos a dficult thing to go through. When you canrsquot talk to anybody apart from your partner about it, then I think that makes it more dficult.ldquoI donrsquot think you should have to take leaveyou donrsquot feel thatrsquos something you need to do, but I think there should be much greater understanding, and society generally should try to adapt a bit more.She said her miscarriage had also been hard on her husband Peter Murrell, chief executive of the SNP.She said: ldquoThatrsquos another part of the taboo. If itrsquos hard for a woman to talk about it, itrsquos possibly even harder for a man, and itrsquos heartbreaking and really traumatic for a man as well.She said people assumed she had taken a ldquoreally hard-nosed decision to prioritise a career over a family.She said ldquoI donrsquot think women should be judged for the reasons why they do or donrsquot have children because men arenrsquot, and itrsquos one of these areas where I do think we still need to see a little bit of progress.Mr Murrell also cropped up when presenter Gloria Hunnord asked Ms Sturgeon who ldquode-stressed her.ldquoItrsquos a daytime show, Ms Sturgeon joked awkwardly. ldquoI love reading books. Thatrsquos the safe answer.What about Peter your husband  Ms Hunnord persisted.ldquoYes, he can de-stress me from time to time, Ms Sturgeon said hiding her face and blushing.The First Minister also said she was backing Green MP Caroline Lucasrsquos call for an all-female emergency cabinet to avoid a no-deal Brexit and call a Peoplersquos Vote..Ms Lucas wrote to a series of senior female politicians proposing the idea at the weekend.Askedshe had responded, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoI have. Irsquom happy to work with anybody - male or female, I have to say - to try to stop Brexit and in particular to try to stop a no-deal Brexit, which I think would be really, really damaging.ldquoIrsquom all for more women in politics. I think we can bring a dferent perspective, but I do feel duty bound to point out the former Prime Minister was a woman and didnrsquot manage to sort out Brexit, so therersquos maybe a flaw in that argument.ldquoIrsquom a big fan of Carolinersquos. I think shersquos a fantastic MP, so Irsquom more than happy to band together with a bunch of other women to seewe can bring some common sense.As the show flitted between topics, Ms Sturgeon also reacted to singer Miley Cyrus splitting from actor Liam Hemsworth after seven months of marriage.Discussing whether to go back out with an ex, she said: ldquoMy philosophy in le tends to be keep moving forward, try not to look back, try not to have regrets.ldquoIn relationships itrsquos not something Irsquove done.
